verb.description: Freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone); hand over to.
examples: the check given to the jeweler proved worthless
they gave her water to drink

verb.description: Cause or allow (someone or something) to have (something, especially something abstract); provide or supply with.
examples: you gave me such a fright
this leaflet gives our opening times

verb.description: Carry out or perform (a specified action)
examples: he gave the counter a polish

verb.description: Yield as a product or result.
examples: milk is sometimes added to give a richer cheese

verb.description: Concede or yield (something) as valid or deserved in respect of (someone)
State or put forward (information or argument)
examples: he did not give his name

verb.description: Alter in shape under pressure rather than resist or break.

noun.description: Capacity to bend or alter in shape under pressure; elasticity.
examples: plastic pots that have enough give to accommodate the vigorous roots

phrases: For everyone, literally for everyone in Sursee, he is simply the priest, and we never feel that he is the kind of parish priest who gives himself airs.
Perhaps if the girl gives herself airs of grandeur, we should encourage her in her ambitions to become the proper lady.
She was not at all like Rebecca, who paraded herself about and gave herself airs.
He gave himself airs so that others could more easily recognize his greatness.
It was as if he was always wary of getting above himself, of giving himself airs and graces, a peculiarly Scottish trait.
his strangely shaped feet gave him away
It was too dark for him to see his attacker, but her voice gave her away.
I saw Jude stride in through the front door. His walk gave him away immediately.
I smiled, hoping my expression wasn't giving me away.
Wilhelm looked down at his feet so his smile wouldn't give him away.
origin: Old English giefan, gefan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch geven and German geben.
